awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Replicated evolution of leaf form in a neo-tropical radiation of Viburnum (Adoxaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Much remains unknown about the genesis of biological diversity, including the origin of new species, yet such knowledge is critical to understand evolution and to make predictions about responses to rapid environmental change. This research will investigate a striking case in a group of trees and shrubs (Viburnum) in which rapid differentiation appears to have occurred repeatedly into two radically different plant forms. Major differences in the leaves of these plants appear to have resulted from adaptation to adjacent forest types that differ subtly in environmental variables. The evident replication of this process in several different mountain regions throughout the New World tropics, provides a rare opportunity to critically test a model of rapid ecological speciation. Detailed studies of adjacent plant populations will be carried out in different mountain regions in Mexico with the aim of identifying the environmental factors and the nature of the variation within populations that have favored the rapid evolution of these leaf traits. It should also be possible to identify genes that underlie these key plant characteristics by taking advantage of natural hybridization between these species. These studies will yield general insights into speciation but also into the adaptive significance of the leaf traits that differentiate related species throughout the flowering plants. This research will be carried out in collaboration with Mexican scientists and will involve multiple undergraduate and graduate students. Outreach activities have been designed to foster interactions between participants from the United States and Mexico.  

This project focuses specifically on understanding the drivers of speciation in three species pairs in the mountains of Eastern and Southern Mexico. The two species in each pair differ dramatically in leaf size and shape (large and round versus small and elliptical), in leaf margins (toothed versus smooth), and in leaf pubescence (densely hairy versus lacking hairs). The research will focus on quantifying variation within individual plants, within populations, and between the species pairs, and on determining the abiotic and biotic factors that differ between their forest habitats. Hypotheses on the adaptive value of the leaf variables will be tested using transects between adjacent habitats and a reciprocal transplant experiment.  In areas that have long been disturbed by indigenous agricultural practices, extensive hybridization has resulted in a wide array of intermediate leaf forms.  Molecular analyses of these hybrid swarms should allow the identification of the major genes that underlie differences in leaf form. 

This project is jointly funded with the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
This award focused on understanding the evolutionary history of a group of flowering plants called Oreinotinus, a subclade of the horticulturally well-know group Viburnum. The 42 species of Oreinotinus inhabit disjunct regions of cloud forest spanning from eastern Mexico to northern Argentina.  In each region there are multiple species that live only there, and they display a repeated set of strikingly different leaf forms: a very small leaf with smooth edges and no hairs on the surface; an intermediate sized leaf with similarly smooth edges; and a very large leaf with teeth along the margins and the surface covered with a dense layer of hairs. We discovered that over the past 10-12 million years these plants migrated from the north to the south, and that the different leaf "ecomorphs" repeatedly evolved independently within each separate mountainous region.  This, then, is the first clear-cut and thoroughly documented case of a "replicated radiation" in plants, adding to well known examples in animals, such as cichlid fishes and caribbean lizards.

Replicated radiations provide exceptional opportunities to understand the mechanisms of evolutionary adaptation. In our focused studies in three regions of Mexico, we quantified the differences in habitat between the different ecotypes.  In our most detailed studies in Chiapas, Mexico, we used data from portable weather stations to show that species with the different leaf forms occupy different ecological niches. Specifically, the species with large hairy leaves occupies wetter and cooler forests in this region, as compared to species with non-hairy leaves.  We also used genetic analyses of inter-species hybrids to understand the genetic architecure of these important traits, and discovered that they are complex and under the control of many genes, making the repeated evolutionary transitions between leaf types even more exceptional. The work that this award funded established Oreinotinus as a model system for studying adaptation, and we predict that it will continue to provide insights into speciation and functional diversification for years to come. In turn, this will improve our ability to predict how plants in these exceptionally diverse and vulnerable cloud forest environments may migrate or evolve in response to global climate change.

This award supported the training of multiple undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates, from the United States and Mexico, an international student workshop on convergent evolution, the development of multiple long-term US-Mexico scientific collaborations, multiple presentations of the work to scientific and public audiences, the development of software for the analysis of molecular data and the dissemination of these tools through several workshops, the acquisition of many plant speciems now stored and available for research in museum collections, and the preparation of multiple peer-reviewed publications.

Modified by: Michael J Donoghue
